description: From German Neutrophil, from neutro- (“neutro-”) + -phil (“-phile”), equivalent to neutro- +‎ -phil.

entries.meaning: (biology, medicine) Of a cell: being more easily or more fully stained by neutral dyes than by acidic or alkaline (basic) ones.
(biology, medicine) Such a cell, especially a particular type of white blood cell.
examples: One litre of human blood contains about five billion neutrophils (around half of all white blood cells).
